questions.text: What is the stage of laryngeal carcinoma shown?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T4aN1MO In the given image, the tumor has crossed the laryngeal cartilage along with the absence of vocal fold mobility on CT/MRI. Thus, it should be denoted T4

Highyeild:

TNM CLASSIFICATION OF CANCER LARYNX Supraglottis T₁ Tumour limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility. T 2 Tumour invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g., mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx T 3 Tumour limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion. T 4 a Tumour invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g., trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or oesophagus). T 4 b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Glottis T₁ Tumour limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility. T₁a Tumour limited to one vocal cord. T₁b Tumour involves both vocal cords. T 2 Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility T 3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion. T 4 a Tumour invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g., trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or oesophagus). T 4 b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Subglottis T 1 Tumour limited to the subglottis. T 2 Tumour extends to vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. T 3 Tumour limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. T 4 a Tumour invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g., trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or oesophagus). T 4 b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures. Regional lymp nodes (N) N x Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. N 0 No regional lymph node metastasis. N 1 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension. N 2 Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph , or nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N 2 a Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N 2 b Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. N 2 c Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension N 3 Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in greatest dimension. Distant metastasis (M) M x Distant metastasis cannot be assessed. M o No distant metastasis. M₁ Distant metastasis. TNM CLASSIFICATION OF CANCER LARYNX (AMERICAN JOINT COMMITTEE ON CANCER , 2002)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- T1 is Tumour limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility. Option B - T2:Tumour extends to supra- and/or subglottic larynx or region outside the supraglottis (with or without impaired vocal cord mobility) Option C - T3:Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space, and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion (e.g. inner cortex)

questions.text: Given alongside is an image of tympanic membrane with retraction pocket. What is the grade of the retraction pocket?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade II Given image shows retraction in both pars tensa and pars flaccida . It is grade 2 retraction as pars flaccida retraction is in contact with neck of malleus while that in pars tensa is in contact with the incus.

Highyeild:

Pars Tensa (SADE classification) Grade 1: Tympanic membrane retracted but not in touch with incus. Grade 2: Tympanic membrane is in contact with a long process of incus. Grade 3:Tympanic membrane is in contact with promontory but not adherent.(middle ear atelectasis) Grade 4: Tympanic membrane is adherent to the promontory. (Adhesive otitis media) Pars Flaccida/Attic retraction grade: (Tosclassification) Grade I - Small attic dimple Grade 2 - Pars flaccida retracted maximally and draped over neck of malleus Grade 3 -As grade 2 with erosion of outer attic wall (scutum) Grade 4 - Deep retraction with unreachable accumulated keratin

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with acute vertigo with horizontal nystagmus. Slow component is towards the left side. What is more likely to be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Hypoactive Labyrinth Slow component of nystagmus will be on the Same side of the Slow (Hypoactive) labyrinth. So Left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on clinical features.

Highyeild:

Horizontal Nystagmus: Ear and lateral canal Vertical Nystagmus : Cerebellar , superior and posterior canal involvement Rotatory nystagmus – Superior canal involvement Rule of Nystagmus: SSS Slow component of nystagmus will be on the Same side of Slow (Hypoactive) labyrinth One of the characteristics of Horizontal nystagmus is the Fast and Slow Fast components gives the direction Mnemonic: COWS Cold water: Opposite side Nystagmus ( Hypoactive) Hot water: Same side Nystagmus (Hyperactive)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and B: are ruled out as both are types of vertical nystagmus. Option D :- Slow component towards left side says that the patient has right sided nystagmus. So the answer must be Right side Hyperactive or Left side Hypoactive.

questions.text: Arrange in order from a cochlear nerve in the hearing pathway Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary Nucleus Medial Geniculate Inferior Colliculus Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A→B→D→C

Highyeild:

Auditory Pathway is order is as follows: E – Eighth nerve C – Cochlear nucleus O – olivary nucleus L – Lateral Lemniscus I – Inferior colliculus M-Medial geniculate A – Auditory cortex Auditory Pathway mnemonic: ECOLIMA Eighth nerve Cochlear nuclei Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - inferior colliculus is before medial geniculate fibres- so this is incorrect. Option C - medial geniculate is not the first in circuit after cochlear nerve. Option D - inferior colliculus is not the first after cochlear nerve.
